data.title: Tempur Sealy: The FTC Has Indicated That It Will Not Seek Emergency Relief From the Fifth Circuit and Will Not Prevent the Transaction From Closing >TPX
Russian Wheat Prices on the Rise — Market Talk
data.description: Higher prices for Russian wheat are Providing support for CBOT wheat futures. Agricultural research firm SovEcon says that the average domestic price for Russian wheat has risen to 15,526 rubles, or $158 per metric ton. In U.S. dollars, that's up 9% since the start of the year, according to SovEcon. The firm says that exporters have been increasingly buying up Russian wheat in recent months, supporting the higher price. However, exports fell back in January, SovEcon says — and Russia's ability to supply wheat to the world may prove to be weaker in 2025 due to troubled weather this winter. CBOT wheat is up 1.1%. (kirk.maltais@wsj.com)

data.title: US Equity Indexes Rise in Midday Trading Following China's Retaliation to Trump Tariffs
data.description:
US equity indexes rose while volatility dropped with the dollar after China announced retaliatory tariffs.

The Nasdaq Composite jumped 1.2% to 19,618.9, the S&P 500 advanced 0.6% to 6,031.6, and the Dow Jones Industrial Average climbed 0.1% to 44,456.8 after midday on Tuesday. Technology, consumer discretionary, and communication services led the gainers intraday.

China plans to impose 15% tariffs on US coal and liquefied natural gas imports and a 10% tariff on crude oil, agricultural machinery, large-displacement cars, and pickup trucks. The move follows the Trump administration's announcement of a 10% additional tariff on imports from China late Friday.

President Donald Trump allowed a 30-day pause in his administration's plan to levy 25% punitive tariffs on Mexico and Canada following telephone conversations with his counterparts in the neighboring countries. Trump will speak with Chinese President Xi Jinping "in the next couple of days," Reuters reported, citing White House press secretary Karoline Leavitt.

The CBOE's Vix index, also known as the fear gauge for investors, slumped 8.3%, and the US dollar index sank 0.9% intraday.

In economic news, US job openings fell to 7.6 million in December, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics, lower than the 8 million openings expected in a survey compiled by Bloomberg and down from the 8.156 million openings reported in November.

US Treasury yields traded mixed intraday. The 10-year was steady at 4.54%, while the two-year fell 4.1 basis points to 4.22%.

West Texas Intermediate crude oil futures fell 3% to $70.95 a barrel.

In company news, Palantir Technologies shares increased 23% intraday, the top performer on the S&P 500 and the Nasdaq, after the company reported late Monday higher Q4 adjusted earnings and revenue. Goldman Sachs adjusted Palantir's price target to $80 from $41.

Merck shares sank 10% intraday, the steepest decliner on the S&P 500 and the Dow, after the company's 2025 guidance for non-GAAP earnings and sales trailed analysts' expectations.

data.title: Beacon Roofing's Valuation Gap With QXO's Takeover Bid Suggests Detailed Outlook on Investor Day, RBC Says
data.description:
Beacon Roofing Supply's valuation gap with QXO's $124.25-per-share bid suggests that company management could present a detailed plan and outlook at its investor day in March, RBC Capital Markets said in a note Tuesday.

Beacon is expected to detail a plan to reach about $1.3 billion to $1.4 billion in adjusted earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, and amortization by 2028, the investment firm said.

The forecast assumes an increase in revenue with about 7% compound annual growth rate, increasing revenues from around $9.8 billion in 2024 to roughly $13 billion in 2028, RBC said.

The valuation plan allocates approximately $0.9 billion for acquisitions and $2.2 billion for share buybacks, reducing the share count by 13 million to roughly 50 million by the end of 2028, the analysts noted.

Although these long-term targets rest on optimistic assumptions, they may form the basis of management's argument to highlight the company's potential value compared to the current QXO offer, according to the note.

RBC maintained an outperform rating and $130 price target for Beacon.

data.title: Willis appoints Mike Giacobbe as Client Strategy Leader, Corporate Risk & Broking, North America
data.description:
NEW YORK, Feb. 04, 2025 (GLOBE NEWSWIRE) — Willis, a WTW business, , today announced the appointment of Mike Giacobbe as Client Strategy Leader for Corporate Risk & Broking, North America. Giacobbe will report to Adam Garrard, Chairman, Global Risk & Broking.

In this new role, Giacobbe will drive an integrated value proposition that brings consistent service across client segments, ensuring every client gets the right, relevant service and expertise for their specific needs. Giacobbe will also focus on maximizing the use of Willis consulting capabilities and analytics tools, working closely with the Risk and Analytics team, tailoring them for clients across North America, whatever their size, industry, location and purchasing patterns.

Giacobbe joins Willis from Marsh, where he was most recently U.S. and Canada Leader of Marsh Advisory, focused on the company’s consulting, analytics and claims advisory capabilities. He was previously Global Head of Data, Analytics & Consulting at JLT, before JLT’s acquisition by Marsh. Before that, Giacobbe was at Aon, where he was latterly Managing Director, Broking, at Aon Risk Solutions after holding leadership positions in Aon’s consulting group. 

Located in Chicago, Giacobbe holds a doctorate in Nuclear Engineering from the University of Illinois. He will join Willis in Q2 2025.  

Adam Garrard, Chairman, Global Risk & Broking, commented:

“We are delighted to have Mike join Willis in this important new role. Ensuring consistency of client service and tailoring our consulting capabilities and analytics tools to the needs of every client, regardless of size, industry, location or purchasing patterns, will distinguish Willis in the North America marketplace.”

About WTW

At WTW , we provide data-driven, insight-led solutions in the areas of people, risk and capital. Leveraging the global view and local expertise of our colleagues serving 140 countries and markets, we help organizations sharpen their strategy, enhance organizational resilience, motivate their workforce and maximize performance.

Working shoulder to shoulder with our clients, we uncover opportunities for sustainable success—and provide perspective that moves you.

Learn more at wtwco.com.

Media contactsDouglas Menelly

Douglas.Menelly@wtwco.com +1 (516) 972 0380

data.title: Tech, Media & Telecom Roundup: Market Talk
data.description:
The latest Market Talks covering Technology, Media and Telecom. Published exclusively on Dow Jones Newswires at 4:20 ET, 12:20 ET and 16:50 ET.

0545 ET - Vodafone is struggling to remain relevant, AJ Bell's Russ Mould writes in a note. "While there are some reasons for encouragement, the market has tuned these out and is focused on the growing problems in its German operation," Mould says. The London-listed telecom company's U.K. segment showed some growth, ahead of the now-approved merger with Three. However, the group needs to demonstrate it can achieve sustainable growth to reassure investors, Mould says. Shares fall 6.3% to 65.62 pence. (najat.kantouar@wsj.com)

0359 ET - Dassault Systemes' new guidance for the current quarter and 2025 as a whole is slightly below market expectations, Bryan Garnier's Aurelien Deside writes in a note to investors. The French software maker is forecasting non-IFRS total revenue between nearly 1.54 billion euros and 1.60 billion euros for the first quarter and between 6.55 billion euros and 6.65 billion euros for the full year. Deside notes that projections for both periods are about 2% below consensus. Dassault Systemes shares trade 0.2% lower at 37.29 euros. (mauro.orru@wsj.com)

0259 ET - Infineon Technologies' sales guidance is slightly ahead of market expectations, Citi analysts write in a note to clients. The German chip maker said revenue would be flat to slightly up in the year to the end of September from the 14.96 billion euros it reported for fiscal 2024, better than a previous forecast of a slight decline. The new projection equates to roughly 15 billion euros against Vara Research consensus of 14.59 billion euros, Citi analysts note. Infineon's guidance lift is mostly driven by expectations of a stronger dollar based on an assumed exchange rate of $1.05 to the euro compared with $1.10 previously. (mauro.orru@wsj.com)

2315 ET - There are high hopes that China may strike a deal with President Trump to delay the additional 10% tariff, after Mexico and Canada managed to delay the U.S. tariffs, says IG. However, there is "still room for surprises and Trump could still come down hard", market strategist Yeap Jun Rong writes in a note. China is seen as a prominent threat to U.S. national security and economic competition, Yeap notes. The tech rivalry between the two countries has become even more pronounced recently with Chinese AI startup DeepSeek, he adds. "But if China can pull it off, risk sentiments may find further recovery momentum, at least in the near term," Yeap says.(amanda.lee@wsj.com)

2212 ET - The rise of Chinese AI is denting investor risk sentiment, particularly in the tech sector, Nomura analyst Naka Matsuzawa says in a research note. This has triggered a flight to quality, driving flows into government bonds, though investor jitters have yet to cause a financial shock or credit contraction, the analyst notes. Meanwhile, U.S. tech earnings have been well-received by the market, helping to ease concerns. Even though this AI-driven shock could erode U.S. economic and market strength over time, the impact of Trump's tariffs is likely offsetting what would have otherwise been a weaker USD, the analyst adds. (tracy.qu@wsj.com)

1849 ET - Shares of Super Micro Computer, which had delayed its earnings while it was looking into accounting issues, are up 9% to $29.27 after-hours as the company schedules a business update for Feb. 11 at 5:00 p.m. ET. A press release refers to a "second quarter fiscal 2025 business update," while the company's website calls it "Fiscal 2Q 2025 results." The Wall Street Journal reported in September that the Justice Department was investigating the server company. Shares surged in early December when Super Micro said a final review showed no evidence of fraud or misconduct by its management or board relating to accounting issues. On Dec. 6, it said it expected to file its delayed financial statements by Feb. 25. (josh.beckerman@wsj.com)

1732 ET - For the past two years, Palantir Technologies has argued that open- and closed-source artificial-intelligence models are becoming more similar, and that performance would eventually converge, Chief Technology Officer Shyam Sankar says on a call with analysts. "That's because the market's been focused on AI supply," he says. "With the release of Deep Seek R1, that has gone from a contrarian position to consensus." Shares jump 22% after the company says demand for its AI products continues to expand. (connor.hart@wsj.com)

1727 ET - Palantir Technologies closed what it called a record number of deals during 4Q, including 32 deals worth $10 million or more. Chief Revenue and Legal Officer Ryan Taylor says on a call with analysts that the company's U.S. business is at the forefront of the artificial-intelligence revolution, with nearly five-times the number of commercial customers from three years earlier and continuing to add more. "Organizations who have crossed the chasm with Palantir are driving real impact quickly," he says. "In this AI revolution the biggest risk is not moving fast enough, and organizations are looking to us." Shares jump 22% in after-hours trading. (connor.hart@wsj.com)

1706 ET - Palantir Technologies blew past analysts' expectations for 4Q and guided for another beat in the current quarter. CEO Alex Karp said in a letter to shareholders that the company's recent results are indicative of a new phase of its business. "The business we have built has now developed its own internal momentum and strength, its own interior life and forms of untamed organic growth, with the output that we are seeing far surpassing what we are investing." He dubs the company a software juggernaut as its stock price jumps 21%, to $101.86, in after-hours trading. (connor.hart@wsj.com)

1312 ET - Apple should be able to manage a 10% tariff hike on China imports, BofA Securities analysts say in a research note. The company has the option to raise prices, but it may choose not to do so at this time, given the small impact of the tariffs, the analysts say. However, if Apple raises prices by a slight amount such as 3% in the U.S. in response to the tariffs, the earnings impact could be offset, even though it may sell fewer units in the U.S. Overall, BofA Securities expects a 5% decline in units sold. Apple shares fall 4%. (sabela.ojea@wsj.com; @sabelaojeaguix)

data.title: ResMed Officer Sells Shares Under Pre-arranged Trading Plan
data.description:
Reporter NameRider Michael J
RelationshipGlobal General Counsel
TypeSell
Amount$15,514
SEC FilingForm 4

Michael J Rider, Global General Counsel of ResMed, sold 64 shares of ResMed Common Stock on February 3, 2025, at a price of $242.42 per share, totaling $15,514. The sale was executed under a Rule 10b5-1 plan adopted on May 11, 2024. Following the transaction, Rider directly owns 8,974 shares of ResMed.

SEC Filing: RESMED INC [ RMD ] - Form 4 - Feb. 04, 2025

data.title: Health Care Roundup: Market Talk
data.description:
The latest Market Talks covering the Health Care sector. Published exclusively on Dow Jones Newswires at 4:20 ET, 12:20 ET and 16:50 ET.

0311 ET - Novartis is set to overcome a wave of patent expirations during 2025, Deutsche Bank analyst Emmanuel Papadakis says in a note. The Swiss pharma giant surprised with its margin performance in the last quarter and its 2025 outlook that came ahead of analysts expectations, he says. While some of the 4Q revenue beat was attributed to rebates, Novartis appears well-positioned to continue exceeding market expectations, the analyst says. Deutsche Bank lifts back the stock rating to buy from hold, which had been previously nudge down due to patent expiry worries. (helena.smolak@wsj.com)

1837 ET - Breathing device maker Fisher & Paykel Healthcare's shares rise 2.5% to claw back some of Monday's steep fall, helped by President Trump agreeing to a monthlong delay to a levy on imports from Mexico. In a note, analyst Matt Montgomerie thinks the tariff threat shouldn't have a material impact on F&P Healthcare's valuation at this stage because the tariffs may ultimately be reversed or revised. Also, F&P Healthcare can shift production back to New Zealand and use Mexico as a hub for other markets. "The latter would take time to implement, but over the long term there shouldn't be a material change in F&P Healthcare's gross margin outlook," Forsyth Barr says. "This is confirmed by F&P Healthcare still expecting to reach its 65% target, albeit two to three years later than its original FY 2027/FY 2028 expectations." (david.winning@wsj.com; @dwinningWSJ)

1655 ET - Fisher & Paykel Healthcare could manufacture more in New Zealand over time as it adjusts to U.S. tariffs on Mexico where it has factories, but such an approach is constrained by staff availability, Jefferies says. F&P Healthcare makes around 45% of its products in Mexico, which President Trump hit with a 25% tariff. "During the pandemic, F&P Healthcare ran its New Zealand facilities 24/7 but shift patterns are currently 16/5 implying considerable ability to increase capacity," analyst Vanessa Thomson says. On staff, F&P Healthcare could benefit from higher unemployment in New Zealand. But this would be partly offset by lower net migration, Jefferies says. "F&P Healthcare would also need new regulatory approval to sell products manufactured in different facilities which may take some months, especially if there is an increase in applications for approval," Jefferies adds. (david.winning@wsj.com; @dwinningWSJ)

data.title: Financial Services Roundup: Market Talk
data.description:
The latest Market Talks covering Financial Services. Exclusively on Dow Jones Newswires at 4:20 ET, 12:20 ET and 16:50 ET.

1216 ET - PayPal is renegotiating deals with large merchants of its Braintree subsidiary and expects to see a resulting 5 percentage point headwind to revenue growth in 2025, CFO Jamie Miller says on a call with analysts. The company is shifting away from some of the volume from the unbranded payment processing unit, which should prove to be accretive to transaction margin dollars, a measure of profitability, according to Miller. "Over the next few quarters, we will continue to work through renegotiations, at which point we should reach a new baseline to drive faster volume and revenue growth," the CFO says. (dean.seal@wsj.com)

1130 ET - PayPal saw total payments volumes for purchases through its Buy Now, Pay Later option jump 21% in 2024 to $33 billion, CEO Alex Chriss says on a call with analysts. Customers that use the deferred payment option spend 30% more on average, and merchants have seen their sales go up after adding messaging around the option to their websites, the CEO says. The company sees Buy Now, Pay Later as a means to expand wallet share and plans to do a lot more with the option over the next year, Chriss says. (dean.seal@wsj.com)

1119 ET - Supply of covered bonds by European banks is expected to decline in 2025, partly due to weak economic growth, ING's Marine Leleux says in a note. ING expects supply of euro-denominated covered bonds to drop by 7 billion euros ($7.24 billion) this year versus 2024. A high number of redemptions due this year could mean bond refinancing dominates covered-bond supply this year, she says.(miriam.mukuru@wsj.com)

1108 ET - PayPal's branded checkout button saw a 6% jump in global volumes on a constant-currency basis in fiscal 4Q, CFO Jamie Miller says on a call with analysts. That's an acceleration of 50 basis points from the prior quarter and driven by a healthy spending environment and exposure in specific verticals, Miller says. PayPal made branded checkout its number one priority in 2024, with a big focus on improving the customer experience, according to CEO Alex Chriss. So far, the company feels good about the desktop experience for branded checkout, but sees "gaps" in the mobile experience, Chriss tells analysts. (dean.seal@wsj.com)

1038 ET - Intesa Sanpaolo's operating profit exceeded consensus and JPMorgan's estimates driven by higher revenue and lower provisions, JPM analysts say in a note. The Italian lender issued a higher-than-expected buyback of 2 billion euros and raised its 2025 net income target to well above 9 billion euros on the back of expected revenue growth and declining costs, the analysts say. "Overall, fee trends are encouraging and the slight step-up in buyback amounts welcome," they say. Shares are up 1.6% at 4.24 euros.(helena.smolak@wsj.com)

1001 ET - The average buyer's agent commission held steady at 2.37% in 4Q, down slightly from 2.45% a year prior, according to Redfin. Despite new commission rules by the National Association of Realtors implemented in August 2024, commissions saw only minor fluctuations, starting at 2.38% in July, dipping to 2.35% in August, and returning to 2.38% by December. A Redfin survey of 500 U.S. agents revealed that 48% said the average agent commission in their area remained about the same since the NAR settlement took effect, while 43% noted a decline. Moreover, 54% of agents reported increased negotiation efforts over commissions by clients, with only 6% seeing less negotiation. (chris.wack@wsj.com)

0645 ET - UBS Group's guidance suggests more top-line pressure to come for its global-wealth-management and personal-and-corporate banking units this quarter, Deutsche Bank's Benjamin Goy and Sharath Kumar say in a research note. The bank guided for a decline in net interest income in global wealth management in the low to mid-single percentage digits this quarter and a 10% decline in the personal and corporate banking unit. While the Swiss bank's fourth-quarter results looked solid, the business mix behind them wasn't ideal, Deutsche Bank says. The group's key global wealth management business was only in line with expectations and its personal and corporate banking unit missed estimates, the analysts say. UBS shares fall 6.1%. (adria.calatayud@wsj.com)

0615 ET - Scor provided a positive update on its January reinsurance-treaty renewals, but this was largely as expected and might not be enough to move the needle, RBC Capital Markets' Derald Goh and Sarah Chong say in a research note. The update points to healthy volumes and flat profit margins, which are consistent with comments the French reinsurer made at its December capital-markets day, the analysts say. "While it's a positive development we think it's largely as expected and hence we do not see anything incremental to sway the story on the back of this," RBC says. Shares rise 3.2%. (adria.calatayud@wsj.com)

0445 ET - Raiffeisen Bank posted a fourth-quarter profit of 128 million euros when excluding its Russia and Belarus operations, Citi analyst Simon Nellis says in a research note. That result brings its year-end result excluding Russia and Belarus to 975 million euros, an 8% miss compared with consensus. Year-end profit for the Vienna-based bank including Russia and Belarus came to 1.16 billion euros, better than Citi had anticipated, the analyst says. Citi says that the bank's result excluding Russia and Belarus, given the number of one-offs the bank faced including a provision and the effect of deconsolidating its Belarus business, is largely in line with expectations. Shares trade 1.6% higher at 20.36 euros. (pierre.bertrand@wsj.com)

0414 ET - BNP Paribas reported strong underlying trends for the fourth quarter and consensus expectations could rise, RBC Capital Markets analyst Anke Reingen says in a research note. The French bank's quarterly result as well as it CET1 ratio exceeded expectations, the analyst says. The bank's new 2024-2026 net income growth rate target suggests at least a 4% consensus upgrade, Reingen says. The slight fall in the bank's 2025 return on tangible equity to 11.5% from a range of 11.5% to 12% previously, given consensus expectations at 10.4%, should offer relief to investors fearing a steeper downgrade. BNP Paribas' targeted revenue growth of at least 5% per year for 2025-2026 is also higher than investors had expected. BNP shares trade 2.5% higher to 65.94 euros. (pierre.bertrand@wsj.com)

0410 ET - BNP Paribas's fourth-quarter profit exceeded market views thanks in part to its corporate and institutional banking business, Barclays analyst Flora Bocahut says in a research note. The company's commercial, personal banking and services division also drove the 4% consensus beat, the analyst says. BNP Paribas's investment and protection services unit disappointed but the business should benefit later this year from external growth, the analyst says. Meanwhile, the bank's targets for 2026 are slightly ahead of consensus, the analyst says. BNP Paribas shares trade 2.7% higher at 66.09 euros. (pierre.bertrand@wsj.com)

0324 ET - Singapore banks' 4Q 2024 earnings are likely to be resilient, says Yeap Jun Rong, IG's market strategist in a note. The bulk of the banks' earnings, which remain supported by net interest income, is expected to stay resilient amid the high-for-longer interest rate environment, he writes. The banks' 4Q loan momentum may also see some pick-up, with data suggesting that overall loans have risen in December from November, he says. Higher confidence around the economy with Singapore's low unemployment rate could have partly contributed to an improvement in lending conditions, Yeap adds. (amanda.lee@wsj.com)

data.title: Energy & Utilities Roundup: Market Talk
data.description:
The latest Market Talks covering Energy and Utilities. Published exclusively on Dow Jones Newswires at 4:20 ET, 12:20 ET and 16:50 ET.

0936 ET - U.S. natural gas futures hand back some of the previous day's gains as weather forecasts continue to vary over how cold February is likely to be. China announced a 15% tariff to be placed on imports of U.S. LNG as of Feb. 10, in response to U.S. tariffs on Chinese goods. "In the immediate term, Chinese offtakers may shy away from U.S.-sourced spot LNG purchases--but U.S. LNG may simply backfill other Asian supply that China lifts instead," Eli Rubin of EBW Analytics says in a note. The tariffs could affect longer-term contracting, however, he adds. The Nymex front month is down 5.2% at $3.177/mmBtu. (anthony.harrup@wsj.com)

0910 ET - Oil futures are lower as China retaliates against U.S. tariffs with duties on U.S. exports including oil and LNG, to take effect Feb. 10. The tariff is particularly negative for WTI, says TP ICAP's Scott Shelton in a note. "I would assume with a $7 tax roughly, that arb is firmly shut and WTI will have to go elsewhere in the next few months as we go into turnarounds." U.S. refineries reduce their crude use during the maintenance season, leading to builds in U.S. crude stocks. WTI is down 2.7% at $71.16 a barrel. Brent is 1.8% lower at $74.61 a barrel. (anthony.harrup@wsj.com)

0321 ET - OMV delivered positive fourth-quarter results underlined by a better-than-expected dividend per share of 4.75 euros, Jefferies analysts Giacomo Romeo and Kai Ye Loh write. The Austrian oil and gas company's net income exceeded expectations by 14% due to a lower-than-expected tax rate and net financial result, they write. Despite reporting profit in-line with expectations, quarterly cash-flow generation was 10% lower than expected, they add. The company's 2025 guidance is now for lower-than-expected capital expenditure of 3.5 billion euros and weak production of 300,000 barrels of oil-equivalent a day, the analysts write. Shares fall 0.9% to 38.84 euros. (adam.whittaker@wsj.com)

1852 ET - The more than 8% drop in Origin Energy's share price that followed a downgrade to annual production guidance for the Australia Pacific LNG project was overdone, contends UBS. The stock reaction ignores several tailwinds that could trigger upgrades to consensus earnings expectations for FY 2026, analyst Tom Allen says. They include a 15%-20% decline in current coal prices, UBS says, noting 45% of Origin's coal costs are unhedged. Origin also wants to expand a battery at the Eraring power station in Australia to become one of the largest battery storage systems in the world. "We do not believe these incremental earnings (A$100 million per annum from 2H FY 2026) are factored into consensus estimates," UBS says. It keeps a buy call on Origin's stock. (david.winning@wsj.com; @dwinningWSJ)

data.title: Basic Materials Roundup: Market Talk
data.description:
The latest Market Talks covering Basic Materials. Published exclusively on Dow Jones Newswires at 4:20 ET, 12:20 ET and 16:50 ET.

0745 ET - China's counter tariffs on U.S. imports aren't expected to have a significant impact on the oil market, according to Commerzbank Research. Beijing said it would impose a 15% tariff on U.S. coal and liquefied natural gas products as well as a 10% tariff on crude oil and other products such as agricultural machinery, effective on Feb. 10. "As China only sourced 1.8% of its crude oil imports from the U.S. last year, the impact on the oil market should be limited," commodity analyst Carsten Fritsch says in a note. (giulia.petroni@wsj.com)

0359 ET - Oil prices fall more than 1% as immediate concerns over supply disruptions ease after U.S. President Trump paused tariffs on Mexico and Canada, the country's biggest foreign suppliers of crude. Brent is down 1.3% at $74.95 a barrel, while WTI falls 2% to $71.70 a barrel. Meanwhile, as a 10% U.S. tariff on Chinese imports came into effect Tuesday, Beijing announced its decision to retaliate with a 15% tariff on U.S. coal and liquefied natural gas imports and a 10% levy on American crude oil and agricultural machinery, starting Monday. The move raised fears of a trade war that could ultimately hurt global growth and dampen demand, putting further pressure on prices. (giulia.petroni@wsj.com)

2244 ET - LG Chem is set to post weaker-than-expected 2025 earnings partly due to sales declines at its electric-vehicle battery and advanced-material businesses, Nomura analyst Cindy Park writes in a note. Park cuts her operating-profit forecast for the South Korean company by 37% for 2025, lowering the valuations of its battery and advanced-material units. Still, she says the stock could gain on a possible earnings improvement for chemicals and a potential cathode restocking at its EV battery affiliate later in the year. Nomura cuts its target price for the stock by 33% to KRW280,000 but keeps a buy rating. Shares are 3.2% lower at KRW215,000. (kwanwoo.jun@wsj.com)

2213 ET - Palm oil prices fall in early Asian trading, tracking weakness in soybean oil on the Chicago Board of Trade, says David Ng, a trader at Kuala Lumpur-based Iceberg X. However, the price weakness won't persist, he adds, citing expectations for weak palm oil output. CPO production for Jan. 1-31 is estimated to have fallen 15% on month, according to Malaysia's Southern Peninsular Palm Oil Millers Association. Ng pegs CPO support at 4,250 ringgit/ton and resistance at 4,400 ringgit/ton. The Bursa Malaysia Derivatives contract for April delivery is 43 ringgit lower at 4,324 ringgit/ton. (yingxian.wong@wsj.com)

1923 ET - Drivers of Westgold's downgrade to FY 2025 production guidance are likely to spill into the following year as well, reckons Macquarie. Westgold expects to produce 330,000-350,000 oz of gold in FY 2025, down from a prior projection of 400,000-420,000 oz. It expects to dig up gold at a higher cost, forecasting all-in sustaining costs, or AISC, of A$2,400-A$2,600/oz. "We also assume the slower ramp-up of Bluebird and Beta Hunt, and softer grades at Big Bell, carry over into FY 2026 and cut production 10% while AISC lifts 4%," says Macquarie, referring to Westgold's mines. Still, Macquarie's revised outlook equates to a 32% year-over-year increase in production in FY 2026. It retains an outperform call on Westgold's stock. (david.winning@wsj.com; @dwinningWSJ)

1858 ET - The proposed 25% tariff on Canadian shipments to the U.S. could cost Rayonier Advanced Materials up to $3.5 million per month while in place, the company said. "Even with these potential tariffs at currently announced levels, the company expects to cover all fixed charges, including maintenance capital and interest expenses," it said. Last year, about 11% of the company's total revenues were generated from Canadian Paperboard exports to the U.S., it added. The company also said it sees 2025 Cellulose Specialties average sales prices increasing mid-single-digit percentage from 2024 levels. (stephen.nakrosis@wsj.com)

1701 ET - Aeris Resources held less cash at the end of 2Q than expected by Ord Minnett, which retains a hold call on the stock as it balances long-term value with a stretched balance sheet. Aeris reported A$26 million in cash at end-December, some A$4 million less than projected by Ord Minnett and despite a lower capital spend. Aeris experienced operational challenges at its Tritton copper mine, with output some 27% below Ord Minnett's forecast and costs around 27% higher. "The Tritton issues appear to have been somewhat rectified as FY 2025 guidance is unchanged with improved grades/tons set to come from Bugderygar, Avoca Tank and Murrawombie," says Ord Minnett, referring to other Aeris-owned pits. (david.winning@wsj.com; @dwinningWSJ)

data.title: Auto & Transport Roundup: Market Talk
data.description:
The latest Market Talks covering the Auto and Transport sector. Published exclusively on Dow Jones Newswires at 4:20 ET, 12:20 ET and 16:50 ET.

1716 GMT - The automotive industry should pursue partnerships over traditional mergers and acquisitions, Bain & Company says in a report. Companies have largely held off on M&A in 2024 amid uncertainty and mounting cost pressures, with deal volumes falling about 60% during the first three quarters of the year, the management-consultancy firm says. But alliances could offer a solution, it notes. "Activity is likely to pick up as companies acknowledge that they can't go it alone much longer," Bain & Company says. (nina.kienle@wsj.com)

1441 GMT - Light-vehicle sales in January indicate Canadian consumers are unperturbed about the economic uncertainty circling over President Trump's trade policy. Research firm DesRosiers Automotive Consultants says its data indicate vehicle sales in January rose 3.1% from the same year-ago month, and in terms of volumes matching the best January ever recorded, back in 2018. On a seasonally-adjusted basis, light-vehicle sales came at a "strapping" 2.15 million, DesRosiers says. The firm adds it's difficult to put January's performance in context, given Trump's tariff threat. As a result, DesRosiers says it's hard to discern whether strong sales were the result of fears over sharply higher car prices, or a sign of solid domestic demand. (paul.vieira@wsj.com; @paulvieira)

1437 GMT - Canada's two railroads, Canadian Pacific Kansas City and Canadian National Railway, would be exposed in the event of a 25% tariff situation with the U.S., but RBC analysts think CPKC would be the most affected. CPKC has 41% of its revenue tied to cross-border trade, according to RBC. Sustained tariffs, the analysts say, over a longer period of time could derail its growth plans. "Moreover, we see many of the company's Investor Day growth targets as dependent on cross-border trade and therefore flag risk to long-term consensus EPS growth estimates should tariffs at current levels be sustained," the analysts say. (adriano.marchese@wsj.com)

1340 GMT - With tariffs paused but still looming, Canada's automotive industry continues to stress the integrated nature of the industry in North America and the damage levies could cause. The Canadian Automotive Partnership Council in a meeting with Canadian lawmakers warned tariffs pose an existential threat to the industry in Canada and the U.S. and costs ultimately being borne by consumers. The industry body notes bilateral automotive trade is balanced, with Canadian exports to the U.S. at C$82 billion and imports at C$79 billion in 2023. And it stresses Canadian-made vehicles don't pose a threat to U.S. automotive jobs or production mandates: fewer than 10% of vehicles sold in the U.S. are produced in Canada, whereas the U.S. assembles about half of the vehicles sold in Canada and exports more vehicles to Canada than to any other country. (robb.stewart@wsj.com; @RobbMStewart)

1008 GMT - Donald Trump's trade policy announcements over the weekend raise the question of whether there is a bigger risk from tariffs to the eurozone than previously thought, according to Capital Economics' Andrew Kenningham. A 10% universal tariff imposed by the U.S. might shave 0.1% to 0.2% off eurozone GDP, he says in a note. But a 25% tariff, as imposed but suspended on Canada and Mexico, would have a more-than-proportionately larger effect because it would be harder for companies and exchange-rate moves to cushion the blow, Kenningham warns. A ball-park estimate is that would cut eurozone GDP by around 0.5%, leaving growth close to zero this year. Additionally, a prohibitive tariff of, say, 100% on European vehicles could on its own push Germany into recession. (edward.frankl@wsj.com)

1001 GMT - TomTom's 2025 guidance is disappointing, ING analyst Marc Hesselink writes in a note. The location technology specialist's outlook remains very uncertain, with no free cash flow expected in the near term, he adds. However, "the guidance provides significant room for error to reflect the uncertain automotive market," he adds. In the fourth quarter, the main negative was its free cash flow--5 million euros outflow--due to unfavorable working capital timing, Hesselink says. Shares are down 14% at 4.28 euros. (najat.kantouar@wsj.com)

1000 GMT - A potential merger between Grab and GoTo would improve margins, Citi Research analyst Alicia Yap writes in a note. Bloomberg reported Tuesday that talks between the ride-hailing companies over a possible combination have recently intensified. They would likely save costs on competing user subsidies, as well as see faster new user acquisition with broader product offerings and better reach to lower-tier cities, Yap says. There could also be better user targeting, cross-selling of financial services and increased advertising revenue on both platforms, Yap adds. Both brands would likely continue running independently, but there could be back-end integration of systems and more collaboration regarding merchant management and sharing their rider and vehicle pool, Yap adds. Citi retains a buy rating on Grab with a target of $5.90. Shares last closed at $4.54. (kimberley.kao@wsj.com)

0233 GMT - Yangzijiang Shipbuilding's record-high order backlog boosts earnings visibility through 2027, DBS Group Research's Pei Hwa Ho says in a research report. The shipbuilder's yards are full through 2027 with an order book of roughly US$24 billion, which is expected to lead to earnings CAGR of around 14% over the next two years, the analyst says. Revenue growth and margin expansion are drivers, as about 65% of the company's order book consists of containership orders that command higher value and margins, the analyst adds. DBS raises its 2024-2026 earnings forecasts for Yangzijiang Shipbuilding by 5%-11%. It raises the target price to S$3.80 from S$2.88 with an unchanged buy rating. Shares are 1% lower at S$3.00. (ronnie.harui@wsj.com)

1806 GMT - BRP, the maker of Ski-Doos and Sea-Doos, says it's working on measures to mitigate the effects of tariffs on its business. The company, which has three manufacturing plants in Mexico as well as its operations in Canada, says in a statement that 25% tariffs will apply to BRP's vehicles, parts, accessories and apparel produced in Canada, and shipped to the U.S. as of Feb. 4. The company says that it has been working on different scenarios and has already implemented "some mitigation measures such as optimizing our shipping plans for exports to our U.S. dealers and building up inventory in our U.S. yards and distribution centers." BRP sinks 9% to C$63.25. (adriano.marchese@wsj.com)

1729 GMT - Auto-technology supplier investors are taking a 'sell now, ask questions later' approach to new tariffs against Mexico, Canada and China, Baird analysts Luke Junk and Benjamin Schmid say in a research note covering companies including Amphenol and Mobileye Global. The market is wondering whether the tariffs are merely a negotiating tactic or could prove to be more durable in the near-term, the analysts say. The tariffs will need to be passed on to consumers to avoid broad supply chain disruptions, they say, drawing a parallel to similar dustups around the chip shortages and inflation of 2021 and 2022. (dean.seal@wsj.com)

data.title: Update: Estee Lauder Fiscal Q2 Adjusted EPS, Net Sales Decline; Q3 Outlook Issued
data.description:
(Updates with the latest stock movement in the first paragraph.)

Estee Lauder shares were down nearly 17% in recent Tuesday trading after the company reported lower fiscal Q2 results.

The company reported fiscal Q2 adjusted net earnings Tuesday of $0.62 per diluted share, down from $0.88 a year earlier.

Analysts polled by FactSet expected $0.32.

Net sales for the quarter ended Dec. 31 were $4 billion, down from $4.28 billion a year earlier.

Analysts surveyed by FactSet expected $3.98 billion.

For fiscal Q3, the company expects adjusted EPS between $0.20 and $0.30. Analysts polled by FactSet expect adjusted EPS of $0.63.

data.title: Snap Reports Earnings Today. Expect Another Big Move for the Stock — Barrons.com
data.description:
By Adam Levine

Snapchat-parent Snap has a lot riding on the company's earnings seemingly every quarter. That could continue Tuesday, when the company is scheduled to report fourth-quarter earnings after the close.

Since 2020, the company's stock has moved by an absolute average of 22% the day after earnings reports. After the fourth quarter 2021 release, the stock was up 59%. Two quarters later, it was down 39%. Last quarter shares rose by 16% after earnings.

"Snap shares don't trade on traditional valuation metrics like near-term GAAP EPS, Free Cash Flow or even Ebitda," Wells Fargo analyst Ken Gawrelski says. "As a result, shares are exceptionally volatile as it feels like there is a referendum every earnings print on future growth."

Oppenheimer analyst Jason Helfstein notes that there is "reasonably high short interest" in the stock, and investors entering or exiting those positions after the earnings release can have a large effect.

He also sees TikTok's saga — will they be banned in the U.S. or not? — as another contributing factor to the volatility. Finally, he noted that Snap's direct response advertising has lagged behind digital ad leaders Alphabet and Meta Platforms, a point of frustration for investors.

Gawrelski has a Buy rating and a $15 price target. Helfstein has a Hold rating and no price target. A quarter of analysts have the equivalent of a Buy, and 68% have a Hold rating. Just three out of 44 analysts have a Sell. The average price target is $13.06.

Sales growth accelerated through the first three quarters of 2024. For the fourth quarter, Wall Street expects $1.55 billion in sales, up 14% from last year, driven by a 9% rise in users and a 5% rise in average revenue per user. Three months ago, Snap guided to $1.54 billion in revenue at the midpoint.

In the 39 quarters that have been reported publicly by Snap, it has seen positive earnings per share once, back in 2021. But it has been able to keep last-twelve-months free cash flow positive, and occasionally uses some of it for share repurchases, including three of the last four quarters.

For the fourth quarter, Wall Street expects the company to report a loss of four cents loss-per-share, up from a loss of 15 cents a year ago, with free cash flow of $161 million.

Write to Adam Levine at adam.levine@barrons.com

This content was created by Barron's, which is operated by Dow Jones & Co. Barron's is published independently from Dow Jones Newswires and The Wall Street Journal.

data.title: Chevron Is Maintained at Hold by Truist Securities
data.description: (17:13 GMT) Chevron Price Target Cut to $160.00/Share From $164.00 by Truist Securities

data.title: 1911 Gold Releases Assay Results From the True North Project
data.description:
1911 Gold Tuesday released assay results from 10 drill holes of the exploration-drilling program currently in progress at the True North Project on the Rice Lake Gold property in Manitoba.

Drill results confirmed the extension of quartz vein hosted, near-surface gold mineralization on both the San Antonio West and Hinge East targets.

Best results included 3.45 meters testing at 2.85 grams per tonne of gold and 4.84 gpt of gold over 3.7 meters

"Now that we are seeing the initial results from our first phase of drilling, we are excited about the potential for a parallel vein structure at San Antonio West, as well as the possible near-surface mineralization at Hinge East," said chief executive Shaun Heinrichs. "A second drill rig will mobilize in the coming weeks as we expand the drill program and continue advancing these targets alongside the ongoing drilling underway at the San Antonio Southeast target."

The company's shares were last seen down $0.005 to $0.195 on the TSX Venture Exchange.

data.title: Pepsi Earnings Beat Expectations. Why the Stock Is Having Its Worst Day Since 2023 — and Why It Could Bounce Back. — Barrons.com
data.description:
By Evie Liu

PepsiCo beat Wall Street estimates for profit in the fourth quarter but missed on revenue. The stock is falling on Tuesday, but some analysts say shares in the snack and beverage giant could bounce back as it invests in new products and further expands internationally.

The maker of Pepsi and Mountain Dew sodas said on Tuesday that adjusted earnings per share were $1.96 in the final three months of 2024. Analysts polled by FactSet expected earnings of $1.94. Revenue came in at $27.78 billion, slightly below the expectations of $27.89 billion.

Pepsi's revenue was hurt by subdued trends in the North America market, with numbers particularly disappointing in the Quaker Foods business, which suffered from a fallout due to product recalls in 2024.

Pepsi shares tumbled 4.4% to around $144 in Tuesday trading, on pace for largest percent decrease since Oct. 5, 2023, when it fell 5.2%. The stock has declined 16% over the past 12 months.

Still, while sales came slightly lower than a year ago, fourth-quarter earnings were up 14% on a constant currency basis.

"Our enhanced multiyear productivity initiatives enabled us to invest in our businesses, and deliver improvements in our gross margin, operating margin expansion and EPS in 2024," said CEO Ramon Laguarta in a statement.

Pepsi, along with many packaged-food companies, has faced some challenges over the past year. Consumers are pulling back from spending amid inflation pressure, while the rising popularity of GLP-1 weight-loss drugs could further dampen appetite for snacks and sugary drinks.

This year, Donald Trump's administration might bring more changes that could negatively affect the food industry, including more prominent labels about harmful ingredients, restrictions on food additives, and cuts to the food stamp program that many low-income households rely on for consumption.

On top of the regulatory pressure, there is also a general trend toward healthier foods. Pepsi's most popular products have historically catered to taste rather than health. The company has been working to evolve its portfolio toward more health and wellness options.

Laguarta said the company will continue to expand in international business, while improving performance in North America. He expects the productivity initiatives to help fund investments and aid profitability.

For 2025, management expects a low-single-digit increase in organic revenue and a mid-single-digit increase in core constant currency earnings per share.

Weaker foreign currencies are expected to hurt revenue and earnings by about three percentage points, the company said. That means a low-single-digit increase to core earnings per share in 2025 compared with 2024 results of $8.16.

Pepsi announced a 5% increase in annualized dividend per share, beginning with the June 2025 payment. Total cash returns to shareholders in 2025 are guided at $8.6 billion, comprised of dividends of $7.6 billion and share repurchases of $1 billion.

Some analysts say uncertainties facing Pepsi might be priced in, and the company is better positioned than peers to grow in the coming years.

"Pepsi's diversified product offering, which includes globally known brands in snacks and beverages, is often a competitive advantage, as it provides a nice mix of at- and away-from-home products," wrote Edward Jones analyst Brittany Quatrochi in a Tuesday note.

The analyst noted that Pepsi's product innovation has driven solid growth in snacks, and it's improving with beverages. With nearly 40% of its sales outside of North America, Pepsi is also geographically diverse.

"International growth, especially in emerging markets, should benefit Pepsi," she wrote. "Usually when people reach the middle class in those markets, they tend to spend more on packaged beverages and snacks."

Pepsi's strong distribution system could help it gain share in those growing markets versus smaller competitors, said Quatrochi, who has a Buy rating for the stock and expects Pepsi to grow earnings at a high-single-digit rate.

Garrett Nelson, a senior equity analyst at CFRA Research also maintained his Buy rating on the stock, but trimmed the 12-month price target to $175 from $190.

Pepsi has a "masterful track record of providing conservative guidance and then exceeding it," he wrote. Despite headwinds, Nelson sees value in Pepsi shares at current levels following the recent slide.

Write to Evie Liu at evie.liu@barrons.com

This content was created by Barron's, which is operated by Dow Jones & Co. Barron's is published independently from Dow Jones Newswires and The Wall Street Journal.

data.title: Update: Spotify Technology Swings to Q4 Earnings as Revenue Rises; Shares Gain
data.description:
(Updates with recent stock move in the headline and first paragraph.)

Spotify Technology shares were over 9% higher Tuesday after the company reported Q4 diluted earnings of 1.76 euros ($1.82) per share, swinging from a loss of 0.36 euros a year earlier.

Analysts polled by FactSet expected earnings of 1.99 euros per share.

Revenue for the quarter ended Dec. 31 was 4.24 billion euros, up from 3.67 billion euros a year earlier.

Analysts surveyed by FactSet expected 4.15 billion euros.

Spotify said it had 675 million total monthly active users in Q4, up 12% year over year.

The company said it expects Q1 revenue of 4.2 billion euros. Analysts polled by FactSet expect 4.17 billion euros.

data.title: SPHERE ENTERTAINMENT NAMES GLENN DERRY EXECUTIVE VICE PRESIDENT, MSG VENTURES
data.description:
SPHERE ENTERTAINMENT NAMES GLENN DERRY EXECUTIVE VICE PRESIDENT, MSG VENTURES

PR Newswire

BURBANK, Calif., Feb. 4, 2025

BURBANK, Calif., Feb. 4, 2025 /PRNewswire/ — Sphere Entertainment Co. announced today that Glenn Derry, an Academy Award winning technologist with over 30 years of industry-defining entertainment technology experience, has joined the Company as Executive Vice President of MSG Ventures.

In this role, Mr. Derry will oversee a wide range of technology initiatives across MSG Ventures, a wholly-owned subsidiary of Sphere Entertainment focused on developing advanced technologies for live entertainment. MSG Ventures also supports Sphere Studios, the immersive content studio dedicated to creating multi-sensory entertainment experiences exclusively for Sphere, and the Sphere platform overall, including future Sphere venues. Mr. Derry will work across the organization to deploy both new and existing technologies that enhance Sphere's live entertainment and experiential content, which has been redefining immersive experiences since the first Sphere opened in Las Vegas in September 2023. He will be based at Sphere Studios in Burbank, and report to Jim Dolan, Executive Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, Sphere Entertainment.

"Our vision for Sphere was to combine cutting-edge technologies with storytelling — bringing audiences together to share in experiences they cannot experience anywhere else," said Mr. Dolan. "Glenn is a creative technologist whose work has had a significant impact on the entertainment industry. His expertise will be an asset to Sphere as we continue to build on this next generation entertainment medium and reinforce our position at the forefront of immersive experiences."

"Throughout my career I have focused on developing technologies in service of creative visions that expand the possibilities of entertainment, and there is no better opportunity to continue that work than at Sphere," said Mr. Derry. "Sphere sets a new standard for immersive experiences, and together with my colleagues across the organization we look forward to creating new tools and experiences that push creative boundaries and drive innovation across the industry."

As one of Hollywood's leading technological innovators, Mr. Derry brings to Sphere extensive experience from various facets of the film and gaming industry, where he is credited with introducing the concept of "virtual production." He joins Sphere Entertainment from AGBO, an Academy Award winning independent film, television, and gaming studio, where he served as President of Production Technology. In this role, he helped lead the establishment of AGBO's innovative virtual production and animation pipelines that service transmedia explorations of the company's intellectual property.

Prior to joining AGBO Mr. Derry served as Vice President of Visual Effects at 20(th) Century Fox Studios following the acquisition of Technoprops, an R&D firm specializing in motion capture and emerging visual production technology. Mr. Derry was the founder and CEO of Technoprops, and over nearly 20 years he built the company into a force recognized for redefining creative and technical innovation in the film industry. Among Technoprops' achievements was developing a state-of-the-art head-mounted camera system widely adopted for capturing an actor's facial movements. Mr. Derry and his team received an Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences Technical Achievement Award for the groundbreaking design and engineering of this system. Over the course of his tenure at Technoprops, Mr. Derry was involved in some of the most technically ambitious projects in film and video games, including Avatar, Star Wars: Rogue One, Avengers — Age of Ultron, Zero Dark Thirty, The Jungle Book, Minority Report, and Halo 4, among many notable others.

Mr. Derry began his career in the film industry creating practical effects, including advanced puppets for movies, before transitioning into his work in visual effects and virtual production.

About Sphere Entertainment Co.

Sphere Entertainment Co. is a premier live entertainment and media company. The Company includes Sphere, a next-generation entertainment medium powered by cutting-edge technologies to redefine the future of entertainment. The first Sphere venue opened in Las Vegas in September 2023. In addition, the Company includes MSG Networks, which operates two regional sports and entertainment networks, MSG Network and MSG Sportsnet, as well as a direct-to-consumer and authenticated streaming product, MSG+, delivering a wide range of live sports content and other programming. More information is available at sphereentertainmentco.com.

Contact:

Sphere Entertainment — spherepr@thesphere.com

View original content to download multimedia:https://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/sphere-entertainment-names-glenn-derry-executive-vice-president-msg-ventures-302367619.html

SOURCE Sphere Entertainment Co.

data.title: Global Commodities Roundup: Market Talk
data.description:
The latest Market Talks covering Commodities. Published exclusively on Dow Jones Newswires throughout the day.

1149 ET - Base metal prices rise, with LME three-month copper up 0.5% at $9,158.50 a metric ton and LME three-month aluminum up 0.6% at $2,636.50 a ton. The market has bounced back from losses incurred by President Trump's proposed tariffs on Canada and Mexico, which have been postponed a month after last-minute agreements on Monday. An additional 10% China tariff has proceeded. This has eased market worries of reduced industrial growth and demand. Canada and Mexico are significant suppliers to the U.S. across the whole base-metals complex, ranging from around 20% of copper imports to nearly half of its aluminum imports. News of the delay also sent the U.S. dollar lower, a tailwind for metals as it becomes cheaper for international buyers to purchase dollar-denominated commodities. (joseph.hoppe@wsj.com)

1141 ET - Gold futures rise, having set a fresh record slightly earlier in the session. Futures are up 0.5% at $2,871.60 a troy ounce, having peaked at $2,874.50 in European late afternoon trading. The precious metal has traded in a relatively narrow range, with rising U.S. bond yields and a stronger dollar limiting the upward rally, XS.com's Rania Gule says in a note. That said, concerns about potential economic fallout from President Trump's tariffs and other inflationary policies provide strong support for gold as a safe-haven asset, Gule writes. The overall upward trend for gold remains intact, and any corrective pullbacks should be seen as buying opportunities as supportive factors haven't fundamentally changed, Gule says. As markets remain uncertain, gold will likely stay a focus for investors both as a hedge and an investment opportunity, Gule adds. (joseph.hoppe@wsj.com)

1132 ET - JBS, the world's largest meatpacker, says it's investing $200 million in two of its largest U.S. beef plants at a time when meatpackers are broadly struggling to make a profit because of a lack of cattle, driving up costs. The company said $150 million will go to its Cactus, Texas, plant to improve the part of the facility where carcasses are processed into primal cuts and expand its ground beef room. JBS says it will put $50 million toward its Greeley, Colo., plant to build a new distribution center. JBS said the investments will improve efficiencies and could increase production capacity at the two plants that both have the capability to slaughter about 6,000 cattle a day. "We believe now is the time to invest in the United States," said Wesley Batista Filho, JBS' U.S. CEO. (patrick.thomas@wsj.com)

1127 ET - U.S. farmers carried an optimistic outlook into 2025, according to the latest Ag Economy Barometer published by Purdue University and the CME Group. Surveyed farmers say that their view of current conditions of the agricultural economy have improved, buoyed by a month of gains for row crop prices on the CBOT. Farmers are increasingly expecting to have a 'more robust' year financially than last year — although some concerns remain. Some 42% of surveyed farmers identified trade policy as their top policy concern over the next five years. Even so, 40% of farmers now say a trade war is likely or very likely, down 8 points from last month's survey. Some 29% say a trade war is unlikely or very unlikely, which is an 8 point increase from last month. (kirk.maltais@wsj.com)

1042 ET - Grain merchant ADM says as part of its plan to cut costs it could shutter or divest facilities that are in need of repair, have a history of poor performance or are located in areas with excess capacity. CEO Juan Luciano said on a call with investors that the company has identified about $2 billion worth of opportunities. The company is facing pressure from low crop prices and falling profit margins in its oilseed processing business. "We will execute on this over time," Luciano said. (patrick.thomas@wsj.com)

1010 ET - Lean hog futures on the CME are higher in early trading, with the most-active contract up 0.8%. Traders appear to be pulling back from the steep selling seen to start the week, with contract limits in today's session extended to 6 cents a pound after the limit-down close Monday, following a drop of 4 cents a pound. While the hog market recalibrates amid tariff turmoil, there exists fundamental pressure points for hog demand. Pork carcass cutout prices shed 94 cents per hundredweight on Monday, according to USDA data, following a strong start to 2025 pricewise. Live cattle futures are down 0.2%. (kirk.maltais@wsj.com)

0952 ET - CBOT grain futures are mixed, with traders maintaining a reserved approach as China responds to Trump tariffs with retaliatory measures of its own targeting energy exports among other things. The tariffs make no mention of raw soybeans, but traders are wondering nonetheless about whether China will curb its purchases. "Remember, we are looking to see if there is any new commodity buying by China, versus just 'maneuvering to avoid tariffs," says Naomi Blohm of Total Farm Marketing in a note. The USDA announced a new flash sale of corn to South Korea for 132,000 metric tons. (kirk.maltais@wsj.com)

0936 ET - U.S. natural gas futures hand back some of the previous day's gains as weather forecasts continue to vary over how cold February is likely to be. China announced a 15% tariff to be placed on imports of U.S. LNG as of Feb. 10, in response to U.S. tariffs on Chinese goods. "In the immediate term, Chinese offtakers may shy away from U.S.-sourced spot LNG purchases--but U.S. LNG may simply backfill other Asian supply that China lifts instead," Eli Rubin of EBW Analytics says in a note. The tariffs could affect longer-term contracting, however, he adds. The Nymex front month is down 5.2% at $3.177/mmBtu. (anthony.harrup@wsj.com)

0928 ET - New U.S. tariffs on Chinese goods were met with retaliation from China, resulting in selling in CBOT soybean futures overnight. But that selling has moderated, with the most-active soybean contract now down only 0.3% pre-market. Traders who have spoken to WSJ say that a lot of market activity has become reactive to new headlines, but is showing restraint in light of trade uncertainty. "I think the trade is well braced for this," says Terry Reilly of Marex. Reilly adds that many traders likely "learned their lesson" after handling the fallout of the trade war with China in Trump's first term. (kirk.maltais@wsj.com)

0922 ET - The dollar recovers some ground after yesterday's choppy session, which ended with a small decline in the WSJ Dollar Index as tariffs on Mexico and Canada were delayed. The trade war with China goes on and markets remain worried about the potential fallout of a prolonged period in which tariffs would loom over the global economy. BBH says in a report that investors should look through the noise and focus on the fact that the U.S. still has strong growth and elevated inflation, "and a more hawkish Fed continues to favor higher U.S. yields and a stronger dollar." The greenback strengthens 0.3 against the yen and is stable versus the euro. (paulo.trevisani@wsj.com; @ptrevisani)

0910 ET - Oil futures are lower as China retaliates against U.S. tariffs with duties on U.S. exports including oil and LNG, to take effect Feb. 10. The tariff is particularly negative for WTI, says TP ICAP's Scott Shelton in a note. "I would assume with a $7 tax roughly, that arb is firmly shut and WTI will have to go elsewhere in the next few months as we go into turnarounds." U.S. refineries reduce their crude use during the maintenance season, leading to builds in U.S. crude stocks. WTI is down 2.7% at $71.16 a barrel. Brent is 1.8% lower at $74.61 a barrel. (anthony.harrup@wsj.com)

0853 ET - ADM falls 2% premarket after saying it expects an uncertain 2025 and posts a 6% decline in sales for the quarter ending Dec. 31 compared with a year ago, and below analyst estimates. ADM says operating profit at its crushing subsegment, which turns oilseeds into oils and biofuels, was 46% lower versus the prior year quarter, because of higher manufacturing costs among other issues. "With softer market conditions and policy uncertainty around the world going into 2025, we are focused on improving our operational performance, accelerating costs savings, and simplifying our portfolio," says ADM CEO Juan Luciano in a statement. (patrick.thomas@wsj.com)

data.title: Canada 10-Year Bond Yield Halts Decline
data.description:
Canada’s 10-year government bond yield stabilized at around 3.04%, halting its decline after reaching seven-week lows, as safe-haven demand eased following Prime Minister Trudeau’s confirmation that U.S. tariffs on Canadian goods would be paused for at least 30 days.

This delay alleviated immediate concerns over potential trade disruptions, which had fueled risk aversion stemming from fears of reduced demand for Canadian exports and limited foreign exchange inflows.

However, the Bank of Canada has taken an increasingly dovish stance, marking the conclusion of its quantitative tightening program, limiting support for yields.

The BoC’s recent 25 basis point rate cut to 3% was accompanied by plans to resume asset purchases starting in March.

Initially, these purchases will occur through the repo program, followed by the acquisition of Government of Canada bills via auctions, with the BoC targeting a return to secondary market bond purchases by the end of 2026.

data.title: Swiss Market Index Closes Lower as Global Trade War Concerns Linger
data.description:
Swiss stocks remained in negative territory, reflecting cautious market sentiment as China strikes back against US tariffs.

The Swiss Market Index was down 0.57% on Tuesday's close.

China unveiled targeted tariffs on select US imports after President Donald Trump's additional tariffs on Chinese goods took effect, Reuters reported. Meanwhile, the European Union is aiming for swift discussions with the US in a bid to avert potential tariffs on the bloc.

"Markets are readjusting after Trump's last-minute deals with Mexico and Canada which delayed tariffs by a month," ING said. "Looking at the implications of Trump's handling of the Mexico and Canada tariff threat, sentiment in the eurozone has improved on the back of expectations that a deal can be struck and protectionism averted."

"Still, extra caution is warranted in this sense. If part of Trump's motive to delay tariffs on US neighbours was domestic backlash for potential immediate economic pain for US consumers, that is not necessarily true for EU tariffs," analysts added.

On the corporate front, UBS Group plunged 7.05% as it reported a drop in 2024 net profit attributable to shareholders to $5.09 billion from $27.37 billion a year before. The Swiss banking group's total revenue, however, rose over the period to $48.61 billion from $40.83 billion.

Meanwhile, SoftwareOne confirmed its plan to list its shares on Euronext Oslo Børs, following Swiss financial market regulator FINMA's recognition of the bourse as a foreign trading venue for Switzerland-listed companies. The secondary listing is part of its planned merger with Norwegian software and cloud technology company Crayon Group, expected to complete in June. SoftwareOne's shares edged down 0.51% at closing.

data.title: Spectrum Brands Likely to Report In-Line Q1, RBC Says
data.description:
Spectrum Brands is expected to report an about in-line fiscal Q1 results, with modest growth in every segment, RBC Capital Markets said in a Tuesday note.

The report also said the firm could face some margin pressure over increased investment. The results are due Thursday.

"We remain positive on the SPB recovery story and think there is a lot to like here, with reasonable potential for upside to FY'25 numbers should guidance prove conservative," RBC analysts, including Nik Modi, said in an earnings preview.

RBC has an outperform rating on the stock with a price target of $114, saying that "SPB is now operating from a position of strength with meaningful optionality/flexibility."

"We think its current stock price does not reflect fair value as a result," the analysts said.

data.title: Toronto Stocks Rebound On Tariff Pause; TMX Group Rises on 4Q Profit, Revenue Beats
data.description:
By Adriano Marchese

Toronto's indexes rebounded on Tuesday at midday from Monday's turmoil, regaining ground after Canada and the U.S. called a month-long pause to the tariffs between the two countries. The reprieve of the pause drove most sectors higher, with tech leading the gainers, followed by health services and consumer services. Only consumer-durables and commercial-services stocks were in the red.

Canada's S&P/TSX Composite Index rose 0.4% to 25342.62 and the blue-chip S&P/TSX 60 rose by 0.2% to 1525.09.

TMX Group shares rose 8% to 48.89 Canadian dollars ($33.89) after the company reported better-than-expected profit and revenue in the fourth quarter and a 5% dividend hike.

Other market movers:

Bombardier shares benefited from the pause, with the stock rising 3.6% to C$85.75 as investors breathed a sigh of relief regarding the pause on tariffs that would have affected deliveries and orders for the business-jet manufacturer.

Write to Adriano Marchese at adriano.marchese@wsj.com
